item.title: Israeli military pulls troops from southern Gaza
item.dc:creator: Yuliya Talmazan and Reuters and Yael Factor
item.description: The Israeli military says it has reduced the number of ground troops in the southern Gaza Strip following the conclusion of its monthslong operation in the city of Khan Younis, raising questions about the future of its offensive in the enclave amid pressure from the U.S. to reduce the war’s humanitarian toll.

media:content.media:text: An Israeli soldier moves atop a tank near the Israeli-Gaza border
media:content.media:description: An Israeli soldier moves atop a tank near the Israeli-Gaza border on April 4, 2024.

item.title: China says it patrolled the South China Sea in an apparent response to U.S. naval drills with allies
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press
item.description: China’s military said Sunday that it had conducted air and sea patrols and that all activities that “disrupt the South China Sea” are under control, an apparent response to naval exercises by the U.S. and its allies.

media:content.media:text: Image:
media:content.media:description: A Filipino port worker looks on as the Japanese Ship Akebono (DD-108), a Murasame-class destroyer of the Japan Maritime Self-Defense Force, prepares to dock for a goodwill visit at Manila's south harbor, Philippines, in Sept. 2018.

item.title: Pellegrini wins Slovak presidential election in boost for pro-Russian prime minister
item.dc:creator: Reuters
item.description: Slovak nationalist-left government candidate Peter Pellegrini won the country’s presidential election on Saturday, cementing the grip of pro-Russian Prime Minister Robert Fico over the country.

media:content.media:text: Image:
media:content.media:description: Slovakia's president-elect Peter Pellegrini.

item.title: Turning point? After deadly strike on aid convoy, Democrats push Biden to put conditions on military help for Israel
item.dc:creator: Dan De Luce and Julie Tsirkin and Frank Thorp V and Megan Lebowitz
item.description: The Israeli airstrike that killed seven World Central Kitchen aid workers has outraged Democrats in Congress and could be a turning point in how Washington sees Israel’s war against Hamas.

media:content.media:text: People gather around the carcass of a car used by aid group World Central Kitchen.
media:content.media:description: People gather around the carcass of a car used by aid group World Central Kitchen that was hit by an Israeli strike in the central Gaza Strip on April 2, 2024.

media:content.media:text: Peter Welch and Jose Andres
media:content.media:description: Sen. Peter Welch, D-Vt., left, walks with chef Jose Andres, founder of World Central Kitchen, at the Capitol on March 14, after a briefing with senators on how to get food aid into Gaza.

media:content.media:text: The passports of World Central Kitchen workers.
media:content.media:description: The passports of World Central Kitchen workers who were killed in the Israeli airstrikes.

media:content.media:text: Gregory Meeks
media:content.media:description: Rep. Gregory Meeks, D-N.Y., at roundtable with family members of individuals being held hostage by Hamas at the U.S. Capitol on November 29, 2023.

item.title: Aid agencies say the Israeli military has been attacking their workers for months
item.dc:creator: Gabe Joselow and Aurora Almendral and Doha Madani and Dan De Luce and Caroline Radnofsky and Matthew Mulligan
item.description: 224 aid workers have been killed since the start of the war, as the death of WCK aid workers highlight the failure of the Israeli military to protect aid workers in line with international humanitarian law.

media:content.media:text: A man displays blood-stained British, Polish, and Australian passports after an Israeli airstrike in Deir al-Balah, Gaza, on April 1, 2024, killed seven World Central Kitchen workers.
media:content.media:description: A man displays blood-stained British, Polish, and Australian passports after an Israeli airstrike in Deir al-Balah, Gaza, on April 1, 2024, killed seven World Central Kitchen workers.

media:content.media:text: Palestinians walking in front of the closed headquarters of the World Central Kitchen on April 3, 2024, west of Nuseirat, central Gaza.
media:content.media:description: Two women walk past the closed headquarters of the World Central Kitchen in central Gaza.

media:content.media:text: Palestinians look a vehicle in Deir Al-Balah, Gaza, on April 2, 2024, the day after it was destroyed by an Israeli airstrike that killed World Central Kitchen workers.
media:content.media:description: Palestinians look at a vehicle Monday in Deir Al-Balah, Gaza, the day after it was destroyed by an Israeli airstrike that killed World Central Kitchen workers.

item.title: Israeli military recovers body of a hostage from Gaza in overnight operation
item.dc:creator: Aurora Almendral
item.description: The IDF said Saturday that it had recovered the body of an Israeli hostage during an overnight raid in the Gaza Strip city of Khan Younis.

item.title: Meet the families who've taken children as young as 2 to Everest Base Camp
item.dc:creator: Aria Bendix
item.description: A handful of families have taken children as young as 2 years old to Mount Everest Base Camp in recent years. Three of them describe the experience.

item.title: Looking for leads, not love: Job seekers in China turn Tinder into a networking tool
item.dc:creator: Larissa Gao and Helen Chen
item.description: Young people in China facing an increasingly tough labor market are turning to an unlikely place for help in their job searches: Tinder.

media:content.media:text: Photo Illustration: A man's Tinder profile reads "Looking for Full-tim employment"
media:content.media:description: Some young people in China see Tinder as a way to find potential job leads.

media:content.media:text: China Youth Unemployment
media:content.media:description: University students at a job fair in Wuhan, China, in March.

item.title: How the Israel-Hamas conflict has spread beyond the Mideast
item.dc:creator: Alexander Smith and JoElla Carman and Jiachuan Wu
item.description: Four months into the war, fighting has spread from Gaza to Pakistan.

item.title: How Taiwan has improved its earthquake preparedness over 25 years
item.description: A 7.4 magnitude earthquake rattled Taiwan, but it isn't the first time a strong quake hit the island. The last deadly earthquake to shake Taiwan was in 1999. NBC News' Valerie Castro reflects on the island's earthquake preparedness improvements in the last 25 years.

media:content.media:title: How Taiwan has improved its earthquake preparedness over 25 years
media:content.media:description: A 7.4 magnitude earthquake rattled Taiwan, but it isn't the first time a strong quake hit the island. The last deadly earthquake to shake Taiwan was in 1999. NBC News' Valerie Castro reflects on the island's earthquake preparedness improvements in the last 25 years.

item.title: Rescue efforts underway for stranded victims in Taiwan national park
item.description: Rescue efforts are underway for stranded earthquake victims in Taiwan national parks. Hundreds of people have been stranded in the park since the earthquake. At least five bodies have been recovered from the debris.

media:content.media:title: Rescue efforts underway for stranded victims in Taiwan national park
media:content.media:description: Rescue efforts are underway for stranded earthquake victims in Taiwan national parks. Hundreds of people have been stranded in the park since the earthquake. At least five bodies have been recovered from the debris.

item.title: Family members of Gaza hostages speak out almost 6 months after terrorist attack
item.description: In an interview with NBC News' Lester Holt, family members of Americans held in Gaza spoke about what their lives have been like since the attack last Oct. 7, the conditions that the hostages have faced during their captivity, and the urgent need for a cease-fire agreement that will lead to freedom for the captives.

media:content.media:title: Family members of Gaza hostages speak out almost 6 months after terrorist attack
media:content.media:description: In an interview with NBC News' Lester Holt, family members of Americans held in Gaza spoke about what their lives have been like since the attack last Oct. 7, the conditions that the hostages have faced during their captivity, and the urgent need for a cease-fire agreement that will lead to freedom for the captives.

item.title: Israel's military dismisses 2 senior officers over killing of Gaza aid workers
item.description: In addition to dismissing two senior officers from their positions, Israel reprimanded three other military officials involved with the airstrikes that killed an American and six other World Central Kitchen workers. The Israeli military said an investigation found that soldiers mistakenly believed armed militants were in the convoy, which was struck. Israel is now opening more aid routes into Gaza following a phone call between President Biden and Israel's Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu. NBC

media:content.media:title: Israel's military dismisses 2 senior officers over killing of Gaza aid workers
media:content.media:description: In addition to dismissing two senior officers from their positions, Israel reprimanded three other military officials involved with the airstrikes that killed an American and six other World Central Kitchen workers. The Israeli military said an investigation found that soldiers mistakenly believed armed militants were in the convoy, which was struck. Israel is now opening more aid routes into Gaza following a phone call between President Biden and Israel's Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu. NBC News' Gabe Gutierrez reports.

item.title: Mexico’s president says his country is breaking diplomatic ties with Ecuador after embassy raid
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press and Joe Kottke
item.description: Mexico is breaking off diplomatic ties with Ecuador after police broke into the Mexican embassy in Quito to arrest a former Ecuadorian vice president who has sought political asylum there after being indicted on corruption.

media:content.media:text: Image:
media:content.media:description: Police break into the Mexican embassy in Quito, Ecuador, Friday. The raid took place hours after the Mexican government granted former Ecuadorian Vice President Jorge Glas political asylum.

item.title: Eight dead in two Russian strikes on Kharkiv, officials say
item.dc:creator: Reuters
item.description: Two Russian strikes on Kharkiv, Ukraine’s second-largest city, killed eight civilians and injured at least 10 early on Saturday and in the afternoon, regional officials said.

media:content.media:text: Aftermath of Russian missile and drone attack in Kharkiv
media:content.media:description: An employee in Kharkiv, Ukraine, on Saturday carries out a door from a fuel station damaged during Russian missile and drone strikes.

media:content.media:text: Aftermath of Russian missile and drone attack in Kharkiv
media:content.media:description: A view shows a fuel station damaged during Russian missile and drone strikes in Kharkiv, Ukraine, on Saturday.

item.title: Heat-trapping carbon dioxide and methane levels in the air last year spiked to record highs again
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press
item.description: The levels of the crucial heat-trapping gases in the atmosphere reached historic highs last year, growing at near-record fast paces, according to the U.S.

item.title: Half a year into the war in Gaza, here’s a look at the conflict by the numbers
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press
item.description: JERUSALEM — The Israel-Hamas war has stretched on for half a year and become one of the most destructive, deadly, and intractable conflicts of the 21st century.

media:content.media:text: Palestinians pray over bodies.
media:content.media:description: Palestinians pray over bodies of people killed in the Israeli bombardment in a mass grave in the town of Khan Younis, southern Gaza Strip on Nov. 22, 2023.

item.title: Families of people kidnapped by Hamas deplore Gaza violence and demand release of hostages
item.dc:creator: Daniel Arkin and Sarah Fitzpatrick
item.description: The families of American citizens kidnapped by Hamas in Israel told NBC News’ Lester Holt that they decry the killings of innocent civilians in Gaza and pleaded with the international community to remain focused on the plight of their loved ones who are still in captivity.

item.title: Ukraine claims it destroyed 6 Russian warplanes in one of its biggest drone attacks of the war
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press and Daryna Mayer
item.description: Ukrainian officials claimed Friday they used drones to destroy at least six military aircraft and badly damage eight others at an airfield in Russia’s Rostov region.

item.title: Her son was last seen badly hurt, being loaded into a Hamas truck: One mother details her 6-month agony
item.dc:creator: Shira Pinson and Matthew Kwiecinski and Yuliya Talmazan
item.description: Rachel Goldberg-Polin is fighting to bring home her son Hersh Goldberg-Polin, who was seized by Hamas from the Nova music festival on oct.7.

media:content.media:text: Kidnapping of Hersh Goldberg-Polin
media:content.media:description: Hersh Goldberg-Polin in an undated family photo.

media:content.media:text: Hersh Goldberg-Polin with his mother and father in an undated family photo.

media:content.media:text: Hersh Goldberg Polin Supernova Music Festival
media:content.media:description: Hersh Goldberg-Polin was partying at the Supernova festival in southern Israel, prior to the surprise attack by Hamas on Oct. 7, 2023.

media:content.media:text: Hersh Gioldberg Polin parents
media:content.media:description: Hersh Goldberg-Polin's parents, sitting alongside their daughter Leebie in Jerusalem, recount their last interactions with their missing son.

item.title: Rescue teams search mountains for trapped Taiwan earthquake victims
item.dc:creator: Janis Mackey Frayer and Andy Yeh and Jennifer Jett and Arata Yamamoto
item.description: Rescuers in Taiwan continued to bring people to safety on Friday and searched for a dozen others still missing from this week’s earthquake, as the death toll increased to 12.

media:content.media:text: Ten people were killed and nearly 1,100 injured in the April 3 magnitude-7.4 quake, but strict building regulations and widespread public disaster awareness appear to have staved off a major catastrophe on the island.
media:content.media:description: Rescue workers searching the Taroko National Park in Taiwan on April 5, 2024 after an earthquake in Hualien days earlier.

item.title: Yellen kicks off China meetings with overcapacity concerns
item.dc:creator: Evelyn Cheng, CNBC
item.description: Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen kicked off her first full day of official meetings in China discussing overcapacity concerns and market-oriented reforms.

media:content.media:text: Image: *** BESTPIX *** CHINA-US-DIPLOMACY
media:content.media:description: Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen, left, with Chinese Vice Minister of Finance Liao Min and U.S. Ambassador to China Nicholas Burns in Guangzhou, China, on Thursday.
